intro: Acacia holosericea var. multispirea, commonly known as the spiral acacia, is a shrub or small tree native to southern Africa. It is characterized by its distinctive spirally arranged phyllodes, which are narrow, linear, and often have a slight zigzag appearance. The plant produces yellow flowers in compact globular inflorescences, typically during the warmer months. Its leaves are modified into phyllodes, reducing water loss in arid conditions. It is often found in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to withstand drought and high temperatures.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia holosericea var. multispirea is primarily native to the arid and semi-arid regions of southern Africa, particularly in countries such as Namibia, Botswana, and parts of South Africa. This variant is commonly found in savannas, rocky outcrops, and dry woodland areas where it thrives in well-drained soils. It is well adapted to the harsh climatic conditions of its native range, including high temperatures and limited rainfall. The plant is often seen growing along riverbanks and in disturbed soils, contributing to the ecological diversity of these regions. Its distribution is largely restricted to the southwestern and central parts of the African continent.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acacia holosericea var. multispirea was mainly introduced to South Africa, where it has become naturalized in certain regions. It is commonly found in semi-arid and coastal areas, particularly in the Western and Eastern Cape provinces. This plant is often associated with disturbed soils and can thrive in a variety of soil types, including sandy and loamy soils. Its introduction has led to its establishment in both natural and urban environments. However, it is not considered invasive in the regions where it is currently found.
